importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: In 2024, 17,195 square kilometres (6,639 sq miles) of forest in Pará were degraded, representing a 421% increase from the previous year, highlighting accelerating deforestation linked to cattle ranching.
Pará’s governor introduced a decree requiring full traceability of animal movements by the end of 2026, signaling a policy shift toward greater supply chain accountability.
The federal Ministry of Agriculture announced a plan to require all states to implement cattle tracking systems by 2032, aiming to improve transparency in livestock supply chains.
JBS signed the G4 Cattle Agreement with Greenpeace in 2009, pledging to identify all indirect suppliers by 2011—a promise it failed to meet, raising concerns about corporate accountability.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: A federal initiative launched in December 2024 mandates that all Brazilian states implement cattle tracking systems by 2032, offering a long-term regulatory solution to deforestation linked to meat supply chains.
Pará’s 2023 decree requires full traceability of animal movements by the end of 2026, aiming to close loopholes in monitoring illegal ranching activities in protected areas.

keyTakeAways: JBS, the world’s largest meat company, is allegedly linked to illegal deforestation in Brazil’s Amazon through its supply chain, particularly in Pará state.
Human Rights Watch found that cattle from illegally deforested land are being 'laundered' through a system that conceals their origin before reaching JBS facilities.
The Brazilian system of animal transit permits (GTAs) does not track individual animals, making it impossible to trace the origin of cattle and thus enabling illegal operations to go undetected.
JBS acknowledged in a 2024 SEC filing that it cannot guarantee compliance with environmental laws due to traceability gaps in the GTA system.

The state of Pará has seen a 421% increase in deforestation from 2023 to 2024, with illegal ranching and land grabs expanding into protected Indigenous and sustainable areas like Cachoeira Seca and Terra Nossa.
Human Rights Watch and environmental groups argue that voluntary corporate commitments, such as JBS’s 2009 pledge, are insufficient and that stronger, enforced government regulations are needed.
Proposals include making GTA data publicly accessible to allow law enforcement and environmental agencies to detect fraudulent movements and identify illegal ranches.
The global climate and environmental community is increasingly holding meat companies accountable for deforestation linked to their supply chains.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A Human Rights Watch report reveals that JBS, the world’s largest meat company, may be contributing to illegal deforestation in Brazil’s Amazon through its supply chain, particularly in the high-deforestation Pará state. The investigation finds that cattle from illegally deforested land are being transported through a 'laundering' system—using Brazil’s anonymous GTA transit permit system—that hides their origins before reaching JBS. Despite JBS acknowledging traceability gaps in a 2024 SEC filing and making promises to trace suppliers by 2026, the lack of individual animal tracking and enforcement makes it impossible to verify compliance. Human Rights Watch and environmental advocates highlight that federal and state governments have slow or incomplete plans to implement full traceability, with Pará’s 2023 decree and the federal Ministry of Agriculture’s 2024 plan set to roll out by 2026 and 2032, respectively. Critics argue that voluntary corporate pledges are insufficient and that stronger, enforceable regulations are needed to hold companies accountable for environmental damage and human rights abuses linked to land grabs in protected Indigenous and sustainable areas.
title: Is your beef linked to Amazon deforestation? A report highlights loopholes
